Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Improving Science Learning in Inquiry-based Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: "Collaborative Research: Improving Science Learning in Inquiry-Based Programs" improves science learning by students who are not achieving their potential in high quality inquiry-based programs. While programs like FOSS, STC and Insights are effective in improving science achievement within and across school districts, many children enrolled in these programs, especially underrepresented minorities and English language learners, fail to demonstrate proficiency on standardized tests of science achievement. This project aims to achieve its goal by developing a computer program, My Science Tutor, which students will use immediately following classroom science investigations to reinforce and extend concepts embedded in the investigations. The program uses a lifelike animated character to engage students in guided learning activities and tutorial dialogs that stimulate scientific reasoning. Tutorial dialogs are based on a proven technique, Questioning the Author, which challenges students to learn to integrate new concepts with prior knowledge to construct enriched mental models that can be used to explain and predict scientific phenomena. To evaluate the intervention, learning gains are compared on standardized tests of science achievement by fourth and fifth grade students in four areas of science by students randomly assigned to three groups: the computer treatment, human tutoring or continued classroom instruction. Formative assessments analyze student and teacher experiences, and learning of concepts and scientific reasoning through analysis of entries in students' science notebooks.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative research demonstrated the feasibility of an inquiry?based computer program to teach elementary level science.

The intellectual merit of the project was its use of open-ended tutorial dialog to encourage thinking and reasoning about science concepts. The broader impact of the project was to contribute new knowledge and evidence supporting the use of conversational tutoring technologies to advance science learning.

The collaboration developed a computer program, in which spoken dialog was used to elicit reasoning of science concepts in tutoring sessions following classroom science investigations. Dialogs were based on the established Questioning the Author approach, which is an inquiry-based tutorial strategy designed to challenge students to integrate new concepts with prior knowledge in order to explain science concepts. An animated character guided students through learning activities to stimulate scientific reasoning. Students were interactively prompted and encouraged to speak about science concepts, with the system taking initiative when it detected partial responses and misconceptions.

New knowledge and techniques for modeling tutorial dialogue and continuous speech were developed. These included schema to annotate not only dialog acts, but also semantic intent in tutorial dialog. An open source speech recognizer was developed through the collaboration, and methods to handle inexact spoken responses were developed, including shallow semantic parses of spoken dialog, rules to match phrases to concepts and misconceptions, and tutorial dialog strategies such as marking and revoicing. The final system was able to recognize spoken words and extract science concepts with meaningful accuracy, and used in feasibility studies.

The collaboration compared learning gains on standardized tests of science achievement for students randomly assigned to different groups: individual computer tutoring, small-group human tutoring, small-group computer tutoring and a control. Moderate effects and statistically significant results were found. One study found no significant difference between individual computer tutoring and small-group human tutoring and that each had meaningfully larger gains than the control group. A second study found no significant difference between individual computer tutoring and small-group computer tutoring and that each had meaningfully larger gains than the control group from the previous year.

The grant supported Ph.D. level research at the University of Colorado, graduating one student, and supporting another who is completing the degree.
